Using Autonomous Recording Units to develop species distribution models for Amphibians in Alberta, Canada Chapter 1 Summary

Using Autonomous Recording Units to develop species distribution models for Amphibians in Alberta, Canada Brandon Allen 2022-01-20 Chapter 1 Summary The Alberta Biodiversity Monitoring Institute (ABMI) has developed a monitoring program for vocalizing amphibians within Alberta. This technical document contains information describing how data was collected, processed, and analysed. This document will be updated as necessary. Readers can find the most up-to-date results on the ABMI Biodiversity Browser (https://www.abmi.ca/home/data-analytics/biobrowser-home).

Chapter 2 Introduction The Alberta Biodiversity Monitoring Institute (ABMI) began deploying Autonomous Recording Units (ARUs) in 2015 to capture the vocalizations of song-birds. These observations have been incorporated into the ABMIs species distribution modeling (SDM) framework that uses supplementary databases (e.g., Boreal Avian Monitoring Project) and methods (e.g., river fork data from 2007-2015) to identify species habitat relationships with native landcover, human footprint, and climate. In addition to capturing vocalizing song-birds, the ABMI has begun identifying vocalizing amphibians. In collaboration with the Bioacoustic Unit, recordings were collected between 2013 and 2021 and are used to create SDMs for vocalizing amphibians. The goal for these models is to identify relationships with native and human footprint landcover types, calculate the impacts of anthropogenic disturbance, and predict the probability of occurrence across the province under both the current landscape condition and a reference condition. This information can be used internally, by stakeholders, or the general public to identify where amphibians are occurring the in the province and how they are impacted by land use changes. 2.1 Expert Review As amphibians are a high profile taxon within the province, the ABMI is implementing a phased rollout of data related to amphibians: Phase 1 (completed May \(1^{st}\), 2021) involved updating our Biodiversity Browser to include occurrence maps of all vocalizing amphibian species detected at ABMI sites (https://abmi.ca); Phase 2 (completed September \(1^{st}\), 2021) involved the development of SDM and an engagement period with local amphibian experts; Phase 3 (completed January \(31^{st}\), 2022) involved synthesizing the advice identified during the expert review phase and updating the models accordingly. The final phase (TBD) will involve incorporating surveys collected by the Bioacoustic Unit and to publish the final set of SDM on the ABMI Biodiversity Browser (https://www.abmi.ca/home/data-analytics/biobrowser-home). We asked the experts to comment on the following topics: Are there gaps in how ARU recordings are currently summarized? Do the habitat relationships identified in the SDMs align with your natural history knowledge of these species? Do the spatial predictions created by the model align with your natural history knowledge of these species current distribution in the province? Are there key habitat or climate variables you feel are essential to capturing amphibian distributions that are currently not included? Would you be comfortable using these results to inform your own personal work? The feedback provided by the experts was synthesized and issues were addressed whenever possible. These models will be under continual development, so we expect improvements as move amphibian surveys are completed and new data layers are made available. We would like to acknowledge and thank our group of experts as their comments during the review process improved the quality of our species models.

Chapter 3 Processing of vocalization events The ARU data used to construct these SDM have come from the following ABMI surveys; Ecosystem Health sites (2015-2021); Adopt-a-Camera/ARU (2017); Citizen Science ARU (2016); Edge-Interior (2017); Northern Focal Areas (2019-2020); Southern Focal Areas (2020); Amphibian Monitoring (2020); and Operation Grassland (2015). Data collected through the Bioacoustic Units Wetlands surveys (2013-2019) was also incorporated. Due to the differences in how ARU data was collected between projects, and the time of deployment, recordings were standardized using the following procedure: Only the first minute of each recording event was listened to. Recordings with high levels of noises due to precipitation, wind conditions, or industrial and background activity were excluded permitting this metadata was available. To replicate the conditions of a midnight survey, we filtered for recording events between 23:30-02:30 hours. We acknowledge that this survey interval may not be optimal for all vocalizing amphibians. Therefore, the calling phenology of each species will be investigated once sufficient data is available. Only species that occurred at greater than 20 ARUs were maintained for analysis. For all species with sufficient data, we assessed the seasonality window of calls by aggregating the percentage of detections across ARUs by Julian calendar day. Local temperature during the recording event and Julian calendar day was used to account for the variation in detectability through the survey window. After cleaning the data, there were 12330 unique recordings used for creating SDMs based on vegetation data (Boreal, Foothills, Canadian Shield, Rocky Mountain, and Parkland natural regions), and 4396 unique recordings used for creating SDMs based on soil data (Parkland and Grassland natural regions).
Chapter 4 Species Distribution Models 4.1 Landcover information 4.2 Vegetation based species models 4.3 Soil based species models 4.4 Reporting Regions

Chapter 4 Species Distribution Models 4.1 Landcover information Landcover information was extracted from the ABMI detailed Wall-to-Wall vegetation and Human Footprint GIS layer. The proportional area of vegetation with broad stand age classes and human disturbance classes (Table. 1) were determined within a 150m buffer by manual interpretation of 1:30,000 aerial photos and SPOT satellite imagery. In regions where vegetation classes do not capture the variation in species distributions, the proportional area of soils, classified into seven broad categories (Table. 1), based on a simplified version of the Agricultural Region of Alberta Soil Inventory Database was used. In addition, we included a term to capture if a site was naturally treed (probability of aspen). Climatic variables (Table. ) were derived from historical weather station data (500 \(m^{2}\) spatial resolution) using the parameter-elevation regressions on independent slopes model (PRISM) method. As amphibians require water for successful breeding, we also calculated the proportion of water within a 1 \(km^{2}\) buffer around each site.To enable provincial wide predictions, the above information was also summarizes as a 1 \(km^{2}\) raster for the entire province. SDMs were created for all species which were detected in at least 20 ARUs within the analysis region (vegetation or soil) using a model selection framework. We created a set of statistcal models (binomial generalized linear models) to relate the relative abundance (presence/absence) of each species to two sets of variables: landcover (vegetation, soil or human footprint) and climate (climate normals and spatial location). This framework allowed us to create models for a large number of species while selecting models for each species that are only as complex as the data supports. For example, the models for a rarer species with few records may not be able to separate different age classes or even broad stand types. In these cases, all age classes or several stand types therefore have the same average value in the resulting habitat model. Table 4.1: Table of landcover features used for the vegetation based models. Class Covariates Age Vegetation WhiteSpruce TRUE Vegetation Deciduous TRUE Vegetation Mixedwood TRUE Vegetation Pine TRUE Vegetation Black Spruce TRUE Vegetation Treed Fen FALSE Vegetation Shrubby Bog FALSE Vegetation Shrubby Fen FALSE Vegetation Graminoid Fen FALSE Vegetation Treed Swamp FALSE Vegetation Shrubby Swamp FALSE Vegetation Marsh FALSE Vegetation Grass FALSE Vegetation Shrub FALSE 4.2 Vegetation based species models Add details about the general modeling framework 4.3 Soil based species models Add details about the general modeling framework 4.4 Reporting Regions We summarize our SDM for three reporting regions: 1) The Forested region is composed of the Boreal, Canadian Shield, and Foothills natural regions and the northern portion of the Dry Mixedwood natural subregion. These areas are predominately impacted by forestry footprint; 2) The Prairie region is composed of the Grassland and Parkland natural regions, the southern portion of the Dry Mixedwood natural subregion, and the eastern portion of the Montane natural subregion. These areas were grouped together due to agriculture being the predominate anthropogenic disturbance; 3) The Rocky Mountain region is composed of the Rocky Mountain natural region exlcluding the eastern portion of the Montane natural subregion. This area has low amounts of footprint (6.2% in 2018) but contains a unique composition of species. The Forested, Prairie, and Rocky Mountain reporting regions.
Chapter 5 Boreal Chorus Frog 5.1 Distribution 5.2 Vegetation Mdoels 5.3 Soil Mdoels 5.4 Linear Features 5.5 Predicted Abundance 5.6 Forested Region 5.7 Prairie Region 5.8 Mountain Region

Chapter 5 Boreal Chorus Frog The Boreal Chorus Frog (Pseudacris maculata) is distributed throughout the entire province of Alberta, where it has been found to breed in small, shallow, wetlands with short grassy vegetation such as meadows, swamps and flooded fields (https://canadianherpetology.ca). In addition, they are also known to occupy flooded agricultural fields and small ponds in urban areas as breeding sites. This aligns with the vegetation based SDM where we predicted the species to have moderate to high abundances in both native wetland land cover and human footprint. Interestingly, we predict high abundances of Boreal Chorus Frog in young cut-blocks. These habitats could have altered landscape properties that allow for shallow emphemeral ponds to form, thus creating attractive breeding sites. 5.1 Distribution The Boreal Chorus Frog was very abundant in our dataset and was detected at 68.6% of survey locations. The occurrence of Boreal Chorus Frog detected between 2013-2021 at ABMI and BU locations. We found that this species exhibited a large seasonality window which started on day 91 and ended on day 181. The frequency of detections across sites aggregated by Julian calendar day. 5.2 Vegetation Mdoels We were able to create SDMs using both the vegetation (AUC = 0.76) and soil (AUC = 0.66) land cover with moderate to poor fit, respectively. The vegetation based model indicated that this species is predicted to have the highest abundance in shrubby swamps, shrubby fens, shrubby bog, and marsh native habitats in addition to high abundance in crops, rough pasture, tame pasture, cut-blocks, and urban industrial footprints. In addition, there was a strong positive effect of MWMT and a positive quadratic relationship with the proportion of surrounding water. The predicted relative abundance (bars) of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of vegetation and human footprint types in the forested region. Black vertical lines represent 90/% confidence intervals and blue vertical lines are added to forest types where harvesting occurs and shows the predicted species abundance in cut-blocks of various ages. 5.3 Soil Mdoels Using the soil based models, we predicted similar levels of abundance in all native and human footprint landcover types with the exception of lower abundance in the other soils type category. Similar to the climate relationships based on the vegetation landcover, there was a positive quadratic relationships with the proportion of surrounding water. The predicted relative abundance (bars) of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of soil and human footprint types in the prairie region. Black vertical lines represent 90/% confidence intervals. The presence/absence of trees affects the presence and abundance of many species; therefore, separate figures are presented for treed and non-treed sites in the prairie region. 5.4 Linear Features 5.5 Predicted Abundance 5.6 Forested Region Local sector Predicted changes to species relative abundance inside areas that have been disturbed by each sector (human footprint type) compared to the habitat it replaced (modelled reference condition with no human footprint). Sector effect values less than 0% indicate habitat suitability is reduced (predicted related abundance is lower) compared to reference conditions, and values more than 0% indicate habitat suitability is improved (predicted relative abundance is higher) compared to reference conditions. Regional sector Predicted change in the total regional population by industrial sector for species. This incorporates the area of the footprint, the native habitats where the footprint occurs, and the species response to a particular footprint. Regional population effect values less than 0% indicate a predicted decrease in the regional population due to a particular sectors footprint, and values greater than 0% indicate a predicted increase. Regional and local sector effects 5.7 Prairie Region Local sector Predicted changes to species relative abundance inside areas that have been disturbed by each sector (human footprint type) compared to the habitat it replaced (modelled reference condition with no human footprint). Sector effect values less than 0% indicate habitat suitability is reduced (predicted related abundance is lower) compared to reference conditions, and values more than 0% indicate habitat suitability is improved (predicted relative abundance is higher) compared to reference conditions. Regional sector Predicted change in the total regional population by industrial sector for species. This incorporates the area of the footprint, the native habitats where the footprint occurs, and the species response to a particular footprint. Regional population effect values less than 0% indicate a predicted decrease in the regional population due to a particular sectors footprint, and values greater than 0% indicate a predicted increase. Regional and local sector effects 5.8 Mountain Region Local sector Predicted changes to species relative abundance inside areas that have been disturbed by each sector (human footprint type) compared to the habitat it replaced (modelled reference condition with no human footprint). Sector effect values less than 0% indicate habitat suitability is reduced (predicted related abundance is lower) compared to reference conditions, and values more than 0% indicate habitat suitability is improved (predicted relative abundance is higher) compared to reference conditions. Regional sector Predicted change in the total regional population by industrial sector for species. This incorporates the area of the footprint, the native habitats where the footprint occurs, and the species response to a particular footprint. Regional population effect values less than 0% indicate a predicted decrease in the regional population due to a particular sectors footprint, and values greater than 0% indicate a predicted increase. Chapter 6 Canadian Toad 6.1 Distribution 6.2 Vegetation Mdoels 6.3 Soil Mdoels 6.4 Predicted Abundance 6.5 Forested Region 6.6 Prairie Region 6.7 Mountain Region

Chapter 6 Canadian Toad The Canadian Toad (Anaxyrus hemiophrys) is distributed throughout the eastern portion of Alberta, where it breeds in wetlands, slow-flowing streams, and ditches that are located in open areas, such as prairies and aspen parkland instead of forests (https://canadianherpetology.ca). This aligns with both our vegetation and soil based models where we predicted Canadian Toad to have low abundances in human footprint features. Interestingly, we predicted high abundances of Canadian Toad in young Pine stands (e.g., Jackpine, Lodgepole pine, Limber pine). In our data set, Canadian Toad was moderately rare with detections at 16.1% of survey locations. 6.1 Distribution In our data set, Canadian Toad was moderately rare with detections at 16.1% of survey locations. The occurrence of Boreal Chorus Frog detected between 2013-2021 at ABMI and BU locations. In addition, Canaidan Toad had a short seasonality window of 45 days, which started on day 121 and ended on day 166. The frequency of detections across sites aggregated by Julian calendar day. 6.2 Vegetation Mdoels We were able to create SDMs using both the vegetation (AUC = 0.76) and soil (AUC = 0.66) land cover with moderate to poor fit, respectively. The vegetation based model indicated that this species is predicted to have the highest abundance in shrubby swamps, shrubby fens, shrubby bog, and marsh native habitats in addition to high abundance in crops, rough pasture, tame pasture, cut-blocks, and urban industrial footprints. In addition, there was a strong positive effect of MWMT and a positive quadratic relationship with the proportion of surrounding water. We were able to create SDMs using both the vegetation (AUC = 0.86) and soil (AUC = 0.83) land cover with good fit. The vegetation based model indicated that this species is predicted to have the highest abundance in young pine native habitats native habitats, and a low abundance in crops, rough pasture, and tame pasture footprints. In addition, there was a strong positive effect of MWMT and a weak negative effect with MCMT. The predicted relative abundance (bars) of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of vegetation and human footprint types in the forested region. Black vertical lines represent 90/% confidence intervals and blue vertical lines are added to forest types where harvesting occurs and shows the predicted species abundance in cut-blocks of various ages. 6.3 Soil Mdoels Using the soil based models, we predicted that this species would have the highest abundance in rapid drain and thin break native habitats, and low abundance in crops, rough pasture, tame pasture, and urban industrial footprints. There was a positive quadratic relationship with MWMT in addition to a weak negative relationship with MAT. As we had good model fit for both the vegetation and soil based models, we created spatial predictions using both models. The predicted relative abundance (bars) of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of soil and human footprint types in the prairie region. Black vertical lines represent 90/% confidence intervals. The presence/absence of trees affects the presence and abundance of many species; therefore, separate figures are presented for treed and non-treed sites in the prairie region. 6.4 Predicted Abundance The predicted relative abundance of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of vegetation, soil, human footprint, and space/cliamte across Alberta under current conditions (2018). The predicted relative abundance of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of vegetation, soil, human footprint, and space/cliamte across Alberta under reference conditions. 6.5 Forested Region Linear features Local sector Regional sector 6.6 Prairie Region Linear features Local sector Regional sector 6.7 Mountain Region Linear features Local sector Regional sector

Chapter 7 Columbia Spotted Frog The Columbia Spotted Frog (Rana luteiventris) are found throughout the British Columbia and the south western portion of Alberta. This species can occur in multiple colorations (tan, shades of brown, grey, olive) but have distinct light centered dark spots on the back. Individuals occupy and breed in wetlands and other permanent aquatic habitats with shallow warm areas and emergent vegetation. They will forage in terrestrial habiats, but hibernate underwater (https://canadianherpetology.ca). 7.1 Distribution The Columbia Spotted Frog was rare in our data set and only detected at 2 of 1648 survey locations. Both locations were in the south western portion of the province. The occurrence of Columbia Spotted Frog detected between 2013-2021 at ABMI and BU locations. As we have so few detections of this species, we are unable to determine the breeding vocalization period. The frequency of detections across sites aggregated by Julian calendar day.

Chapter 8 Great Plains Toad The Great Plains Toad (Anaxyrus cognatus) are found in the south eastern portion of Alberta grasslands. This toad usually light brown or olive with light-borded dark blotches and light stripes. With such a small distribution in Alberta, the Great Plains Toad is found in both shallow natural and anthropogenic waterbodies (e.g., dikes, ditches). This species burrows deep in the soil to avoid the dry period and hiberate (https://canadianherpetology.ca). 8.1 Distribution The Great Plains Toad was rare in our data set and only detected at 4 of 1648 survey locations. All detections were within the Grassland natural region of Alberta. The occurrence of Great Plains Toad detected between 2013-2021 at ABMI and BU locations. As we have so few detections of this species, we are unable to determine the breeding vocalization period. The frequency of detections across sites aggregated by Julian calendar day.

Chapter 9 Northern Leopard Frog The Northern Leopard Frog (Rana pipiens), despite its name, occupies the eastern portion of Alberta. They are green or brown with distinct dark spots. This species occupies fish free waterbodies and spends extensive time foraging in terrestrial habitats. During winter, they will hiberate at the bottom of large waterbodies (https://canadianherpetology.ca). 9.1 Distribution The Northern Leopard Frog was rare in our data set and only detected at 1 of 1648 survey locations. This detection was observed in the Canadian Shield. The occurrence of Northern Leopard Frog detected between 2013-2021 at ABMI and BU locations. As we only have one detection of this species, we are unable to determine the breeding vocalization period. The frequency of detections across sites aggregated by Julian calendar day.

Chapter 10 Plains Spadefoot The Plains Spadefoot (Spea bombifrons), similar to the Great Plains Toad, occurs in the southern portion of the Alberta Grasslands. They are grey, brown, or olive with reddish spots and often match their local substrate. This species occupies shallow natural and anthropogenic waterbodies (e.g., temporary ponds, ditches, etc) and burrows to avoid dry conditions. They hibernate in deep burrows they dig themselves, or use unoccupied mammal burrows (https://canadianherpetology.ca) 10.1 Distribution The Plains Spadefoot was rare in our data set and was detected at 11 of 1648 survey locations. All observations were found in the Grasslands natural region. The occurrence of Plains Spadefoot detected between 2013-2021 at ABMI and BU locations. As we have so few detections of this species, we are unable to determine the breeding vocalization period. The frequency of detections across sites aggregated by Julian calendar day.
Chapter 11 Western Toad 11.1 Distribution 11.2 Vegetation Mdoels 11.3 Soil Mdoels 11.4 Predicted Abundance 11.5 Forested Region 11.6 Prairie Region 11.7 Mountain Region

Chapter 11 Western Toad The Western Toad (Anaxyrus boreas) is distributed throughout the western and central areas of Alberta. This species breeds in shallow aquatic habitats, such as the edges of lakes, rivers, and ponds (https://canadianherpetology.ca). Outside of the breeding period, this species occurs in a variety of wetland, forest, meadow, and scrubland habitats. This aligns with our vegetation based model, which predicted that Western Toad would have increased abundances in native wetland habitats, and low abundances in crop, tame pasture, rough pasture, and urban industrial human footprint. Similar to Boreal Chorus Frog, we observed high abundances of Western Toads in cut-blocks which could provide shallow ephemeral ponds surrounded by native vegetation that are suitable as breeding sites. However, our models are unable to identify if the high abundance in cut-blocks leads to successful breeding events or if these habitats are acting as population sinks on the landscape. 11.1 Distribution We found that Western Toad was relatively rare in our data set and was detected at 11.5% of sites. The occurrence of Boreal Chorus Frog detected between 2013-2021 at ABMI and BU locations. This species had the second largest seasonality window (75 days), which started on day 91 and ended on day 166. The frequency of detections across sites aggregated by Julian calendar day. 11.2 Vegetation Mdoels We were able to create SDMs using only the vegetation land cover (AUC = 0.84) which had good fit (Table. ). The vegetation based model indicated that this species is predicted to have the highest abundance in shrubby swamps and treed fren native habitats, low abundance in crops, rough pasture, tame pasture, and urban industrial footprints, but high abundance in young cut-blocks (Figure. ). In addition, there was a strong positive effect of MAT and latitude, though strong negative effects of AHM and long (Figure. ). The predicted relative abundance (bars) of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of vegetation and human footprint types in the forested region. Black vertical lines represent 90/% confidence intervals and blue vertical lines are added to forest types where harvesting occurs and shows the predicted species abundance in cut-blocks of various ages. 11.3 Soil Mdoels Using the soil based models, we predicted similar levels of abundance in all native and human footprint landcover types with the exception of lower abundance in the other soils type category. Similar to the climate relationships based on the vegetation landcover, there was a positive quadratic relationships with the proportion of surrounding water. The predicted relative abundance (bars) of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of soil and human footprint types in the prairie region. Black vertical lines represent 90/% confidence intervals. The presence/absence of trees affects the presence and abundance of many species; therefore, separate figures are presented for treed and non-treed sites in the prairie region. 11.4 Predicted Abundance The predicted relative abundance of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of vegetation, soil, human footprint, and space/cliamte across Alberta under current conditions (2018). Chapter 12 Wood Frog The Wood Frog (Lithobates sylvaticus) occupies most of Alberta, except for the southern portions of the Grassland natural region. This species is associated with deciduous and boreal forests and breeds in shallow, ephemeral wetlands, but may also breed in flooded ditches, roads, and the shallow bays of lakes (https://canadianherpetology.ca). This aligns with both our vegetation and soil based models where we predicted Wood Frog to have high abundances in human footprint features. In addition, our vegetation based models predicted increased abundances in native wetland habitats, as well as young mixedwood and intermediate deciduous forests. 12.1 Distribution The Wood Frog was common in our data set and was detected at 41.9% of sites. The occurrence of Boreal Chorus Frog detected between 2013-2021 at ABMI and BU locations. This species had the earliest seasonality window, which started on day 91 and ended on day 151. The frequency of detections across sites aggregated by Julian calendar day. 12.2 Vegetation Mdoels We were able to create SDMs using both the vegetation (AUC = 0.67) and soil (AUC = 0.77) land cover with poor to moderate fit. The vegetation based model indicated that this species is predicted to have the highest abundance in fens, marsh, and shrub native habitats, as well as high abundance in crops, rough pasture, tame pasture,young cut-blocks, and urban industrial footprints. In addition, there was a positive quadratic relationship with the proportion of surrounding water. The predicted relative abundance (bars) of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of vegetation and human footprint types in the forested region. Black vertical lines represent 90/% confidence intervals and blue vertical lines are added to forest types where harvesting occurs and shows the predicted species abundance in cut-blocks of various ages. 12.3 Soil Mdoels Using the soil based models, we predicted that this species would have high abundance in loamy native habitats, but would have even higher abundance in crops, rough pasture, tame pasture, and urban industrial footprints.There was a strong negative relationship with longitude in addition to a weak negative relationship with latitude, MAT, and an interaction between latitude and longitude. The predicted relative abundance (bars) of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of soil and human footprint types in the prairie region. Black vertical lines represent 90/% confidence intervals. The presence/absence of trees affects the presence and abundance of many species; therefore, separate figures are presented for treed and non-treed sites in the prairie region. 12.4 Predicted Abundance The predicted relative abundance of Boreal Chorus Frog as a function of vegetation, soil, human footprint, and space/cliamte across Alberta under current conditions (2018).
